    Design, Optimization, and Structural Characterization of an Apoptosis-Inducing Factor Peptide Targeting Human Cyclophilin A to Inhibit Apoptosis Inducing Factor-Mediated Cell Death

    Abstract

    Blocking the interaction between the apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF) and cyclophilin A (CypA) by the AIF fragment AIF(370–394) is protective against glutamate-induced neuronal cell death and brain injury in mice. Starting from AIF(370–394), we report the generation of the disulfide-bridged and shorter variant AIF(381–389) and its structural characterization by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) in the free and CypA-bound state. AIF(381–389) in both the free and bound states assumes a β-hairpin conformation similar to that of the fragment in the AIF protein and shows a highly reduced conformational flexibility. This peptide displays a similar in vitro affinity for CypA, an improved antiapoptotic activity in cells and an enhanced proteolytic stability compared to the parent peptide. The NMR-based 3D model of the AIF(381–389)/CypA complex provides a better understanding of the binding hot spots on both the peptide and the protein and can be exploited to design AIF/CypA inhibitors with improved pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamics features.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The interaction of the apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF) with cyclophilin A (CypA) plays a key role in vitro and in vivo in pathways of programed cell death.
    The AIF is a flavoprotein with NAD(P)H oxidase and monodehydroascorbate reductase activities localized in the inner mitochondrial membrane.(1,2) Genetic downregulation of the AIF, as in Hq mice, causes progressive loss of terminally differentiated cerebellar and retinal neurons, resulting in ataxia and blindness, respectively. Such progressive neurodegeneration is associated with complex I deficiencies.(3−5) These findings indicate that the AIF has a vital role in mitochondrial bioenergetics and cellular redox metabolism.(6)
    However, many reports also provide evidence of a lethal function of the AIF.(7) Under pathological conditions, the AIF is released from the mitochondria in its proapoptotic form [AIF(Δ1-121)] and translocates into the nuclei, where it induces the chromatin condensation and large-scale DNA fragmentation, ultimately leading to caspase-independent cell death.(8−10) Selective targeting of AIF mediates protection against excitotoxic cell death, oxidative stress, and ischemic injury of the nervous system.(11−15) As an example, the overexpression of Hsp70 family members prevents AIF nuclear translocation and provides cytoprotection in primary cortical neurons and in SH-SY5Y neuronal cells.(16) Also, the microinjection of neutralizing antibodies against AIF blocks N-methyl-d-aspartate/poly(ADP-ribose)polymerase-1 (PARP-1)-dependent excitotoxicity in neurons and PARP-1-dependent cytotoxicity in fibroblasts.(9) Moreover, siRNA-mediated AIF gene silencing or its genetic downregulation in Hq mice provides neuroprotective effects in vitro and against brain damage after focal cerebral hypoxia/ischemia damage in vivo.(17−19)
    Overall, these findings demonstrated the importance of having tools for the selective regulation of the lethal function of the AIF without altering its vital activity. In this regard, several in vitro and in vivo models of programmed cell death have shown that AIF(Δ1-121) cooperates with the peptidyl prolyl cis–trans isomerase CypA to mediate cell death.(5,20−22) Disruption of the CypA homologue CPR1 in yeast cells inhibits cell death induced by overexpression of AIF.(23) Jurkat cells lacking CypA expression are relatively resistant to AIF-induced cell death and this effect is reversed by reintroduction of the CypA gene.(20) Downregulation of CypA reduces the sensitivity of AIF-induced cell death during glutamate-mediated oxidative stress.(21) CypA knockout (CypA–/−) confers significant neuroprotection in neurons following hypoxia–ischemia in the neonatal rat brain.(19) Noteworthily, the detrimental cooperation between the AIF and CypA does not rely on the CypA peptidyl-prolyl cis–trans isomerase activity,(20) and unlike Hq mutant mice, CypA–/– mice are phenotypically normal, showing that the selective targeting of CypA has a high potential for limiting AIF-mediated damage. The amino acid region of AIF(Δ1-121) mainly involved in the interaction with CypA has been identified.(21) A peptide mimetic of this region (henceforth called AIF(370–394)) binds CypA in the low micromolar range (KD = 5 μM) and is able to compete with the AIF(Δ1-121) protein for the binding to CypA. The transfection of AIF(370–394) in HT-22 neuronal cells blocks the AIF/CypA complex formation and, like CypA downregulation, significantly reduces the oxidative stress and ameliorates the survival of cells treated with high doses of glutamate.(21) Moreover, the prior intranasal delivery of AIF(370–394) to pups subjected to hypoxia–ischemia damage significantly reduces brain injury for both the gray matter and the subcortical white matter within 72 h after the damage.(24) Notably, a very recent seminal work has shown that AIF(370–394) can efficiently reduce myocardial cell death and has the potential to prevent sudden cardiac death in patients with arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy, a disease that provokes approximately 400,000–460,000 death every year only in the United States.(25) This finding greatly expands the importance of AIF as a therapeutic target and urges the development of inhibitors for medical intervention.
    The structural characterization of the AIF(Δ1-121)/CypA and AIF(370–394)/CypA complexes has demonstrated that the region on CypA interacting with AIF(370–394) is included in that used to bind the AIF, in line with the ability of the peptide to inhibit AIF(Δ1-121)/CypA complex formation.(26,27) Moreover, the interacting surface of AIF(370–394) is located on the rim of the catalytic site of CypA, which agrees with the inability of the peptide, as well as of the AIF protein, to inhibit the catalytic activity of the enzyme.(26,27) Taken together, the data show that the AIF(370–394) represents a simplified but effective ligand model to study the AIF/CypA interaction and to design selective inhibitors of the lethal complex. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) studies of the AIF(370–394) peptide, which adopts a β-hairpin conformation in the AIF protein,(28) have shown that its interaction with CypA induces a more organized structure, suggesting that the stabilization of the secondary structure elements could increase the affinity of the peptide for CypA. To further expand this working hypothesis, we designed and tested a set of constrained AIF(370–394) analogues identifying a stapled bicyclic peptide with an affinity for CypA in the nanomolar range.(29) The structural data coupled with molecular modeling analyses indicated that this improved affinity derived from a balance between an increased conformational stability and a partially retained flexibility that likely favors an induced-fit mechanism of recognition.
    Here, we report the generation of a disulfide-bridged and shorter variant of AIF(370–394) and its structural characterization by NMR in the free and CypA-bound state.
    In particular, we have designed a 11-mer stapled peptide [hereafter, AIF(381–389)], which displays a similar in vitro affinity for CypA, an improved antiapoptotic activity in cells, and an enhanced proteolytic stability compared to the parent peptide. A 3D molecular model of the AIF(381–389)/CypA complex has been built using NMR data, providing an atomistic view of the binding hot spots on both the peptide and the protein. These data can be exploited to design with high confidence new inhibitors of the CypA/AIF complex with improved pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic features and to develop drug candidates for therapeutic purposes.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Design, Synthesis, and Characterization of a Size-Reduced Version of AIF(370–394)

    Starting from previous structural and biochemical information on AIF(370–394) and its stapled analogues,(26,27,29) we tried to improve the peptide structural features by reducing the size and addressing its potency and stability. In particular, we removed the amino- and carboxy-terminal portions, which turned out to be less involved in the binding with CypA.(27) We thereby focused our attention on the AIF residues encompassing the region from Leu380 to Glu390 (single letter sequence: LIKLKDGRKVE; Table S1, Supporting Information) and started to investigate the corresponding synthetic peptide. Since this region assumes in the native AIF protein a β-hairpin conformation, two cysteine residues (Cys) were added at the amino- and carboxy-termini of the peptide to potentially stabilize the β-hairpin structure through the formation of a disulfide bridge.(30) The linear (reduced) and oxidized peptides (hereafter called AIF(380–390)red and AIF(380–390)ox, respectively) were evaluated for their ability to bind CypA using a label-free Corning Epic technology, and the results are reported as KD values (Table 1). As shown in Figure 1A,B, both peptides bind CypA in a dose-dependent and saturable manner. The fitting of the binding curves with a nonlinear regression algorithm showed a 1-log improvement in potency of the cyclic peptide compared to the linear variant (Table 1). To evaluate the role of the individual side chains of AIF(380–390)ox in the binding, Ala-scan variants were prepared (Table S1, Supporting Information) and tested at two concentrations (10 and 20 μM) against CypA (Figure 1C). Binding experiments showed that peptides with alanine in place of K382, K384, R387, and K388 had lower affinity for CypA compared to the parent peptide (AIF(380–390)ox). On the contrary, peptides with alanine replacing L380, I381, L383, and V389 showed substantially unaltered binding affinity compared to AIF(380–390)ox. Remarkably, peptides where D385, G386, and E390 were replaced by alanine had higher affinity for CypA than the parent peptide. These findings suggested that AIF(380–390)ox binds CypA with an affinity similar to that of the parent peptide AIF(370–394) and that the basic residues K382, K384, R387, and K388 are mainly involved in the interaction with the target, in line with previous results.(27)
    Table 1. KD Values of AIF Peptides Underlying the Binding with CypAa
    peptideKD (μM)
    AIF(380–390)red30.0 ± 2.8
    AIF(380–390)ox3.2 ± 0.2
    AIF(381–389)2.4 ± 0.2
    a

    KD values were obtained by concentration-dependent binding experiments for each peptide.

    Since L380 only negligibly affected the binding to CypA and the replacement of E390 with alanine increased the affinity, we replaced them with cysteines (CysN-ter and CysC-ter), thus keeping residues 381–389 connected by a disulfide bridge that could potentially stabilize a β-hairpin structure (Table S1, Supporting Information). The new cyclic peptide [henceforth called AIF(381–389)] was tested in binding experiments against CypA, as described above. As shown in Figure 1D and Table 1, the peptide AIF(381–389)-bound CypA with a KD in the low micromolar range, demonstrating that, in agreement with the alanine scanning experiments, the deletion of the two residues L380 and E390 does not affect the affinity for CypA of the resulting peptide.

    Resonance Assignment and Chemical Shift Analysis of the AIF(381–389) Peptide

    In order to evaluate the conformational determinants governing the protein–peptide recognition mechanism between the cyclic peptide AIF(381–389) and the protein CypA, we first investigated the peptide in the free form by natural-abundance NMR spectroscopy.
    A nearly complete 1H, 15N, and 13C chemical shift assignment at 298 K (Tables S2 and S3, Supporting Information) was obtained using a previously published strategy,(31) in which, by exploring the natural isotopic abundance, heteronuclear 2D [1H–15N] HSQC and 2D [1H–13C] HSQC were analyzed using the 1H resonances assignment obtained by inspection of homonuclear 2D [1H–1H] TOCSY and 2D [1H–1H] ROESY spectra (Figure S1, Supporting Information).
    First, the 1H–15N HSQC spectrum showed a good dispersion of the backbone N–HN cross-peaks in both proton and nitrogen dimension, suggesting that AIF(381–389) has a preference for structured conformations.(32,33) In addition, as illustrated in the Figure 2A–C, the experimental Hα, Cα, and Cβ chemical shifts significantly deviate from random coil values predicted by using several methodologies,(34−38) indicating that the peptide adopts an ordered secondary structure. In particular, the positive deviations of Hα and Cβ, as well as the negative Cα secondary chemical shifts (δobs–δcoil) suggest that residues included in the Ile381–Leu383 and Lys388–CysC-ter regions have a significant β-strand propensity. In line with this assumption, the differences between Cα and Cβ secondary chemical shifts (ΔδCα–ΔδCβ)(39) for the residues located at the N- and C-terminal regions are lower than 2 ppm (Figure 2D). Noteworthily, the profiles of the secondary chemical shifts obtained for Hα protons and for Cα and Cβ carbons fit well with those expected for a β-hairpin structure: two stretches of positive ΔδHα and ΔδCβ and negative ΔδCα corresponding to β-strands are connected by some residues having negative ΔδHα and ΔδCβ and positive ΔδCα. Among this central amino acid region, Lys384 exhibits a negative ΔδCβ and highly positive ΔδCα values, the well-known feature for the i + 1 residue of type I′ β-turns.(40,41) The presence of a β-hairpin conformation was also indicated by medium- and long-range ROE connectivities detected in the 2D [1H–1H] ROESY spectrum. In particular, HN Asp385 shows a strong ROE correlation with the HN of the previous (Lys384) and the successive (Gly386) residue. The amide proton of the Gly386 displays a ROE cross-peak with Lys384 Hα, whereas Ile381, Lys382, and Leu383 show strong long-range ROE connectivities with Arg387, Lys388, and Val389 (Figure 2E). Similar analyses performed on the linear variant of the peptide showed that it does not show any preferential conformation (Figure S2, Supporting Information), suggesting that the β-hairpin conformation is stabilized by the presence of the disulfide bridge (Table S4, Supporting Information).

    Structural Characterization of AIF(381–389)

    To get deeper insights into the β-hairpin formed in solution by AIF(381–389), we determined the three-dimensional structure of the peptide by using NMR spectroscopy (Figure 3A–E). The structure calculation was performed using ROE-driven distances (Figure 3B), hydrogen bonds, and backbone dihedral angles (ϕ,ψ) as conformational restraints (see the Experimental Section). Additionally, secondary structure elements of AIF(381–389) were evaluated by vicinal 3JHNHα scalar couplings analysis. According to the chemical shift index (CSI) (Figure 3A) and amide proton temperature coefficient (ΔδHN/ΔT), the 3JHNHα coupling values are >8 Hz for the residues located in two terminal regions (CysN-ter-Leu383 and Lys388-CysC-ter) (Figure 3C and Table S5, Supporting Information), confirming the presence of β-strand conformations. As reported in Figure 3D, the superposition of the 20 lowest energy structures of the AIF(381–389) indicates that the backbone of the resulting NMR conformational ensemble is well defined, especially at the turn region (Leu383–Gly386). In particular, considering all residues from CysN-ter to CysC-ter the pair-wise root-mean-square deviation (rmsd) value for the backbone atoms of the 20 selected structures is 0.037 Å, suggesting that most of the residues are characterized by a reduced conformational flexibility (Table S6, Supporting Information). On the contrary, side chains are less ordered (Figure 3E), as reflected by the increase in the pair-wise rmsd value (0.97 Å) (Table S6, Supporting Information) when all heavy atoms are considered.
    Notably, the overall stability of the β-hairpin structure is supported by (i) the disulfide bridge between the CysN-ter and CysC-ter, (ii) the Ile381–Val389 and Leu383–Val389 hydrophobic interactions, and by (iii) an extensive network of hydrogen bonds involving the backbone atoms. In more detail, the carboxyl oxygen of the Ile381 interacts through a hydrogen bond with the amide proton of the Val389. The backbone amide of the Leu383 is involved in the hydrogen bond with the carboxyl oxygen of the Arg387, whereas the carboxyl oxygen of the Leu383 interacts through a hydrogen bond with the amide proton of Asp385 and Gly386, respectively. The carboxyl oxygen of the Lys384 is hydrogen-bonded with the HN of the Gly386. In addition, the carboxyl oxygens of the Asp385 and Gly386 are involved in hydrogen bonds with the HN of the Arg387 and Lys388, respectively.

    AIF(381–389) Backbone Dynamics

    Further insights on the structural properties of AIF(381–389) were provided by the investigation of the 15N backbone motions of the peptide in the microsecond to millisecond (μs–ms) and in the picosecond to nanosecond (ps–ns) timescales by natural abundance NMR spectroscopy. For the evaluation of peptide dynamics on different timescales, a combined approach was used, in which the dynamical information contained in the backbone chemical shifts was integrated with the data obtained by measuring a couple of 1H–15N HSQC spectra filtered with different relaxation-compensated CPMG (Carr–Purcell–Meiboom–Gill) periods (125 and 500 ms)(31) (Figure S3A,B, Supporting Information). In fact, in this HSQC-based experiment, also called T2-filter 1H–15N HSQC, only the 1H–15N cross-peaks of the residues with a 15N transversal relaxation time (T2) longer than the applied filter delay are detectable. As reported in Figure S3A (Supporting Information), the T2-filter 1H–15N HSQC spectrum of AIF(381–389), acquired using a filter delay of 125 ms (R2 = 1/T2 = 8 Hz), contains the 11 expected 1H–15N cross-peaks with a comparable intensity, indicating that all residues are characterized by a 15N R2 self-relaxation rate lower than 8 Hz. On the contrary, the T2-filter 1H–15N HSQC experiments measured, using a filter delay of 500 ms (R2 = 2 Hz; Figure S3B, Supporting Information), do not contain the 1H–15N cross-peaks (15N R2 faster than 2 Hz) of Ile381, K382, K388 Val389, CysC-ter, and Asp385, whereas the NMR signals of CysN-ter, L383, K384, G386, and R387 show a significant intensity reduction (Figure 3F). These results thus demonstrate that the regions encompassing the two β-strands (β1 = Ile381–K382; β2 = Lys388–Val389), together with the Asp385 placed in the middle of the β-turn, are slightly more rigid than the rest of the peptide in the μs–ms timescale. To explore the conformational dynamics of the peptide in the ps–ns timescale, the model-free order parameter S2 was estimated. The S2 value represents a measure of the partial restriction of the H–N bond in the ps–ns timescale in a molecule-fixed frame and assumes values between 0 (large motion) and 1 (no motion). The order parameter S2 values obtained in the range between 0.51 and 0.72 (Figure 3G) indicate that AIF(381–389) adopts a β-hairpin structure in solution characterized by a reduced conformational flexibility also in the ps–ns time scale.

    Mapping of the Binding Site of CypA on AIF(381–389)

    The AIF(381–389)–CypA interaction was first described by investigating the chemical shift perturbation (CSP) and intensity ratio of the peptide resonances upon binding to CypA. In particular, 1H–15N HSQC and 1H–13C HSQC spectra of unlabeled AIF(381–389) in the presence of CypA (peptide/protein 150:1 M ratio) were acquired. Notably, a subset of AIF(381–389) resonances in the 1H–15N HSQC spectrum (Figure 4A), as well as in the 1H–13C HSQC experiment (Figure 4B), showed significant changes upon addition of CypA, indicating that several AIF(381–389) residues were involved in the binding mechanism. The 1H, 15N, and 13C shift variations were evaluated by dividing the chemical shifts into three groups: backbone (ΔH,N,Cbackbone), side chains (ΔH,N,Cside-chain), and all together (ΔH,N,Call-together) (Figure 4C). Significant backbone and side-chain CSPs, as well as the ΔH,N,Call-together values, were observed for Lys382, Asp385, Gly386, Arg387, and Lys388. Additionally, the comparison of the HN/N and Hα/Cα cross-peak intensities of AIF(381–389) in the absence and presence of CypA showed a significant signal reduction for Lys382, Asp385, and Lys388 (Figure 4A,B), confirming that these residues play a major role in the recognition mechanism.
    Taken together, the CSP data and the intensity profile analysis indicate that the recognition of CypA by AIF(381–389) is principally mediated by Lys382 and Lys388, located in β1 and β2 strands, respectively, and by Arg387 and Asp385 situated in the β-turn. These results well agree with the Ala-scanning experiments reported above and with previous results obtained on AIF(370–394) in complex with CypA.(27) Indeed, it was shown that the strongest interactions are established by the peptide-charged groups on lysine and aspartate side chains, explaining the preserved CypA binding affinity of the new peptide compared to the parent peptide.

    Mapping of the Interaction Site of AIF(381–389) on CypA

    To identify the binding site of AIF(381–389) on CypA, we acquired the 1H–15N HSQC spectrum of 15N-labeled CypA in the presence and absence of the peptide (molar ratio protein/peptide 10:1) (Figure 5A,B). Largest CSPs on CypA were observed for Tyr48 and Cys52–Arg55 (β3), Gly59 (type II turn between β3 and β4); Thr68, Arg69, Gly74, Gly75, Lys76, and Tyr79 (turn between β4 and β5); Ser99–Ala103 (β5); Gln111 and Thr116 (β6); Thr119 (the 310-helix); and Val127, Val128 (β7), and Ser147 (type I turn) (Figures 5C,D and S4, Supporting Information). We also analyzed the NMR signal intensity variations of CypA upon addition of AIF(381–389) and the relative ASA (accessible surface area) (Figure 5E). These data were combined with CSPs in order to identify the CypA residues directly involved in the binding to the peptide and discarding the residues for which the chemical shift variations are related to indirect binding effects (i.e., allosteric change). As shown in Figures 5F and S4 in Supporting Information, the recognition mechanism of AIF by CypA is mainly mediated by Thr68, Arg69, Gly72, Gly75, Asn102, and Ala103. These residues, located in a shallow hydrophobic pocket on the CypA surface, flanking the catalytic site, were used as ambiguous interaction restraints (AIRs) in the molecular docking studies reported in the next paragraph.

    Structure of the AIF(381–389)/CypA Complex

    To provide an accurate description of the molecular determinants driving the AIF(381–389) binding to CypA, a structural model of the AIF(381–389)/CypA was calculated using the data-driven docking program HADDOCK.(44,45) To take into account the molecular motions and include this information in the determination of the AIF(381–389)/CypA structural model, we used the whole NMR ensemble (20 conformers) of the AIF-derived peptide in the docking protocol calculated as reported above. In the case of CypA, we generated a conformational ensemble (51 conformers) by molecular dynamics simulations and cluster analysis techniques (see the Experimental Section) using the X-ray crystal structure (PDB ID: 2CPL) of the protein as the template (Figures S5 and S6, Supporting Information). Additionally, in the docking protocol, we defined the AIRs between AIF(381–389) and residues of CypA based on the integrated analysis of NMR (i.e., CSPs and intensity profile analysis) and structural data (i.e., ASA; see the previous paragraph and the Experimental Section) (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The docking calculation generated 200 solutions that were next clustered using a 5 Å rmsd as the cutoff based on the pairwise backbone rmsd. This procedure resulted in 16 clusters, which were then ranked according to the HADDOCK scores calculated by evaluating the intermolecular energy. In addition, the docking structures were also clustered considering the Z-score values that indicate the standard deviation from the average of a particular cluster in terms of the HADDOCK score (the more negative the better). The top two clusters (cluster1 = 41 structures; cluster2 = 11 structures) had HADDOCK scores of −53.1 ± 12.7 and −40.3 ± 3.4 and Z-scores of −2.3 and −0.7, respectively (Figure S6, Supporting Information). Therefore, the representative structure from cluster1, which had the lowest HADDOCK and Z scores of any cluster and was more in line with the NMR structural data, was accepted as the reference structure of the complex (Figure 6A–F). The structural model of AIF(381–389)/CypA clearly indicates that the AIF-binding surface of CypA is mainly composed residues located in the loop region included between the β4 and β5 strands (Figures 6A and S7, Supporting Information). As illustrated in Figure 6A–C, AIF(381–389) binds CypA into a shallow groove of the protein surface with specific contacts flanking its catalytic site. In detail, the four basic residues Lys382, Lys384, Arg387, and Lys388 of AIF(381–389) form the major contacts with CypA (Figure 6D–F): Lys382 and Lys388 side chains point in the same direction interacting through hydrogen bonds with the carboxyl oxygen atoms of the Glu81 of CypA (Figure 6D); Lys384 interacts with Lys76 of the protein, and the Arg387 guanidinium group is hydrogen-bonded with the carboxyl oxygen atoms of Asn71 (Figure 6F). Additionally, the recognition of CypA by AIF(381–389) is further stabilized by the interaction of the Asp385 of AIF(381–389), which forms a hydrogen bond with Lys76 of CypA.
    The validation of the selected structure of the complex AIF(381–389)/CypA was performed through in silico alanine-scanning mutagenesis experiments.(46) Data obtained, in line with the experimental data previously described, predicted that Lys382, Asp385, Arg387, and Lys388 are the key residues in the binding to CypA (Figure S8, Supporting Information), supporting the reliability of the AIF(381–389)/CypA structural model obtained.
    Furthermore, as revealed by the ConSurf bioinformatics analysis (Figure 6B), the residues of CypA recognized by the peptide AIF(381–389) are situated in a region of the protein that shows a high degree of conservation with homologous proteins, suggesting a mechanism of ligand recognition conserved among the different variants and involving the residues surrounding the catalytic pocket.

    Serum Stability of AIF(381–389)

    Proteolytic degradation of peptides is a major weakness of this class of molecules, largely limiting the systemic administration.(47) We thereby evaluated the susceptibility of the oxidized AIF(381–389) peptide to degradation in the presence of human serum as compared to the linear precursor AIF(370–394). The disappearance of the intact peptides incubated in human serum at 37 °C was monitored by RP-high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) for 12 h. As shown in Figure 7, the linear peptide AIF(370–394) was quickly degraded with a half-life of less than 4 h and almost disappeared after 6 h. In contrast, the cyclic AIF(381–389) was remarkably resilient toward the degradation. In particular, a slight decrease was observed after 2 h, but the process did not proceed further over the next 6 h. After 12 h, more than 75% peptide remained in solution.

    Biological Evaluation

    To investigate the biological activity of AIF(381–389), we assessed the peptide ability in protecting the mouse hippocampal (HT-22) neuronal cells from oxidative glutamate toxicity. In HT-22 cells, the prolonged exposure to high concentrations of glutamate induced cell death by a process involving AIF/CypA nuclear translocation.(21) Previously, we showed that the delivery of the peptide AIF(370–394) in HT-22 cells significantly reduced neuronal damage induced by glutamate at a level similar to that observed by the siRNA downregulation of CypA.(21) Here, HT-22 cells were transfected with 50 μM of both AIF(381–389) and AIF(370–394) using the Pro-Ject protein transfection kit (for details see the Experimental Section). Then, 24 h after transfection, glutamate was added to the cells at three different concentrations (5, 6, and 7 mM), and the cell viability was detected by the MTT assay upon 16 h of glutamate exposure. First, we assessed if the peptide provided cytotoxic effects. As shown in Figure 8, AIF(381–389), similar to AIF(370–394), does not exhibit cytotoxic effects on cultured neuronal cells under the tested conditions (cell viability above 90%). Moreover, the MTT assay not only shows that the AIF(381–389) is able to attenuate the glutamate-mediated toxicity, as noted for the AIF(370–394), but also provides a greater neuroprotective effect compared to the parent peptide. Indeed, HT-22 cells treated with AIF(381–389) exhibit an increased survival (up to 10–20%) compared to those treated with AIF(370–394) and compared to the control cells (up to 20–30%) (Figure 8). These preliminary findings show that the new peptide can provide enhanced biological activity in living cells, as compared to the parent peptide.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The AIF/CypA complex is becoming an ever-important target for treating several diseases, and peptide-based inhibitors are showing a promising efficacy as potential therapeutics.(20,21,24,25) We have here described a potential new lead peptide and determined the structure of the complex it forms with CypA by NMR. The molecule has been identified through a process of size reduction and sequence optimization of the previously reported peptide AIF(370–394) and its stapled analogues, which bind CypA and are selective inhibitors of the complex.(21,24,25) The new peptide spans residues 381–389 of AIF and is cyclized through a disulfide bond connecting two cysteines added at the C- and N-terminal ends of the chain.
    AIF(381–389), despite its small dimensions, less than half the size of the precursor, shows an affinity in vitro comparable to that of AIF(370–394). However, it should be noted that AIF(381–389) has a reduced potency compared to the previously reported AIF(370–394) stapled analogue, which shows a KD in the very low micromolar range (KD = 0.85 μM).(29) These results indicate that the interaction of AIF(370–394) with CypA involves residues from the N- and C-terminal ends of the peptide as already reported in previous studies(27,29) and also that the loss of affinity is likely compensated by the conformational constriction of AIF(381–389) in its native conformation. The cyclization significantly restricts the conformational space explored by AIF(381–389), resulting in the formation of intramolecular hydrophobic interactions between the residues Ile381–Val389 and Leu383–Val389 and an extensive network of hydrogen bonds involving the backbone atoms, which significantly stabilize the native β-hairpin structure adopted by the fragment free in solution. Noteworthily, the improved conformational rigidity of the peptide enabled further structural investigations to elucidate the molecular basis of the interaction between AIF and CypA by NMR in depth, as compared to that obtained with AIF(370–394) and stapled AIF(370–394). In fact, the high flexibility of the linear peptide and the low solubility of the stapled AIF(370–394) precluded a detailed structural characterization by NMR analysis either free in solution or in complex with CypA.(27,29)
    Data here obtained show that, similar to what was suggested for AIF mimetic peptides in previous 3D molecular models, AIF(381–389) binds CypA into a shallow groove flanking the protein catalytic site and establishes specific contacts mediated by the AIF residues Lys382, Arg387, Lys388, and Asp385, demonstrating that it retains high selectivity for the binding site of the target. The new peptide shows a remarkably higher resistance to degradation in human serum and an improved ability to prevent cell death in a cellular model of glutamate-induced neurotoxicity compared to the AIF(370–394) parent peptide. Considering the instability of disulfide bonds in the cytoplasm due to the reducing conditions, the improved biological activity observed with AIF(381–389) is probably even underestimated. Further improvements of the biological activity are expected by replacing the unstable disulfide bridges with isosteric more stable bonds (e.g., triazole bridges or thioethers).(48)
    Despite the relevant role played by the AIF/CypA complex in pathways critical for programed cell death, no clinical inhibitors of the complex have been developed to date. This is certainly due to the lack of reliable structural data; therefore, we strongly believe that the identification of a new small and compact peptide inhibitor of the AIF/CypA complex and the detailed understanding of its recognition mechanism with CypA are the crucial steps toward the generation of drug candidates for therapeutic intervention in neurodegenerative and cardiac diseases underpinning the nonphysiological activity of the AIF. The structural data here provided are thereby very useful for drug development programs based on structure–activity relationship studies and on computational approaches for improving the druggability of the peptide and to predict new highly effective, target selective, stable, and cell-permeable inhibitors.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Materials

    Protected amino acids, coupling reagents (HATU), and Fmoc-Rink Amide AM Resin used for peptide synthesis were obtained from GL Biochem (Shanghai, PRC). The solvents, including CH3CN, DMF, trifluoroacetyl (TFA), CH3OH, sym-collidine, DIPEA, and piperidine were obtained from Merck (Milan, Italy). Analytical HPLC analyses were performed on an Alliance HT Waters 2795 system, equipped with a PDA Waters detector 2996. Preparative purifications were carried out on a Waters 2545 preparative system (Waters, Milan, Italy) fitted with a Waters 2489 UV/visible detector. LC–MS analyses were performed using an ESI Ion Trap HCT ETD IIHC Ultra PTM Discovery system Bruker mass spectrometer coupled with an HPLC System Alliance e2695 separation module fitted with a 2998 PDA detector (Waters, Milan, Italy). An EnSpire Multimode Plate Reader (PerkinElmer, Monza, Italy) was used to perform label-free assays.

    Peptide and Protein Preparation

    The peptides were synthesized following the Fmoc methodology as previously described in the literature.(49) The peptides were cyclized by dissolving the linear peptides with cysteines at N- and C-termini at a concentration of 10–3 to 10–4 M in 0.015 M ammonium carbonate pH 8.0 for 24 h under agitation at room temperature. The reactions were monitored by analytical HPLC, and at the end, after acidification with TFA, the mixtures were lyophilized and directly used for preparative HPLC purification. The linear peptide was similarly obtained, skipping the cyclization step. Peptide purification was carried out using an Onyx monolithic semi-PREP C18 column, operating at a flow rate of 15 mL/min using H2O + 0.1% TFA (solvent A) and CH3CN + 0.1% TFA (solvent B) as solvents. The linear gradient used for the elution was: 0–70% of solvent B for 20 min. Purity and identity of peptides were assessed by analytical RP-HPLC and LC–MS (Figure S9, Supporting Information).(50) The yields of the target peptides, calculated as [(experimental weight of pure peptide)/(theoretical weight) × 100], where the theoretical weight was calculated on the basis of the synthesis scale used, were estimated to be around 60%. The relative purity of peptides was calculated as the ratio of the peak area of the target peptide and the sum of areas of all detected peaks from the UV chromatograms at 210 nm. The purity of all peptides was >95%.
    Recombinant His6-tagged-CypA, 15N-labeled CypA, was efficiently expressed in BL21(DE3) Escherichia coli cells, purified to homogeneity and characterized as previously reported in the literature.(26,27) The protein concentration was determined by reading the absorbance at 280 nm using a NanoDrop2000c UV–vis spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific, USA). The concentration of the peptides, lacking tryptophan and tyrosine residues, was determined via the Scopes method,(51) in which the absorbance of the peptide bond was monitored at 205 nm by a NanoDrop200c UV–vis spectrophotometer.

    Corning Epic Label-Free Technology

    Binding assays were performed using the Corning Epic label-free technology on the EnSpire multimode plate reader, as previously reported (PerkinElmer, Rodgau, Germany).(27) In brief, CypA immobilization on the optical biosensors was accomplished by adding 200 μg/mL protein in 20 mM sodium acetate, pH 5.5, using a 12-channel Thermo Scientific matrix multichannel equalizer pipette followed by overnight incubation at 4 °C. The microplate was subsequently washed three times with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS, pH 7.4) buffer. After the washing steps, the samples coated on wells were equilibrated in the assay buffer (PBS) for 3 h (30 μL) and subsequently, a baseline was recorded. After another washing step, 15 μL of peptides were dispensed in the plate wells. Peptides were diluted with the assay buffer (PBS) at a working concentration of 300 μM (150 μM final concentration in the plate) and then further diluted in the assay buffer directly in a 384-well polypropylene plate for a total of 12 different concentrations. The final readings were taken over a period of 1 h. The difference between the last baseline measurements and the maximum signal was used to determine the KD value. Graphs were generated using GraphPad PrismR V-5.01 (GraphPad Software, La Jolla, CA). The results are means of triplicates.

    Serum Stability Assay

    The peptides were mixed with 10% FBS to a final concentration of 2.0 mg/mL and incubated at 37 °C. Aliquots of 50 μL taken after 0, 30, 60, 120, 240, 360, and 720 min were mixed with 100 μL of 90% ethanol and incubated on ice for 15 min. After centrifugation (12,000g, 2 min), the supernatant was diluted with 0.1% TFA in H2O (1:1). The samples were analyzed by RP-HPLC on a C18 Onyx column (2.0 × 50 mm, 5 μm), applying a linear gradient from 5 to 70% of solvent B (0.1% TFA in CH3CN) over solvent A (0.1% TFA in water) in 20 min at a flow rate of 0.6 mL/min. All stability tests were performed at least in triplicate.

    Cell Culture of HT-22 and Transfection

    HT-22 cells were cultured at a density of 10,000 cells/well in a 96-well plate (Greiner Bio-One, Frickenhausen, Germany) at 37 °C and 5% CO2 in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle medium (Invitrogen, Karlsruhe, Germany) with 10% heat-inactivated calf serum and 100 U/mL penicillin, 100 μg/mL streptomycin, and 2 mM glutamine. The transient transfection of the peptides was performed using the cationic lipid mixture Pro-Ject protein transfection reagent kit according to the manufacturer’s instructions (Pierce, Thermo Scientific, Munich, Germany, Prod no. 89850).

    Cell Viability Assay

    The quantification of cell viability in HT-22 cells was performed in standard 96-well plates by the method of MTT (Sigma-Aldrich) reduction. Then, 24 h after peptide transfection, the glutamate-mediated oxidative stress(21) was induced by adding to HT-22 fresh medium containing high concentrations of glutamate (5, 6, and 7 mM) (Sigma-Aldrich, Munich, Germany). Therefore, the cell viability was evaluated between 14 and 16 h later. The reagent was used at 0.25 mg/mL for 1 h. After terminating the reaction by removing the media and freezing the plate at −80 °C for at least 1 h, the MTT dye was dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and absorbance was determined at 590 nm with the blank obtained at 630 nm (FluoStar OPTIMA; BMG Labtech, Offenburg, Germany). The cell viability levels were determined by comparing absorption of treated cell samples with that of untreated control cell samples (100% cell viability). The DMSO control was used as the solvent control. The results obtained are shown as a percentage of controls set at 100%. The data are representative of the mean ± S.D. of at least four technical replicates.

    Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Measurements

    NMR experiments were performed at 298 K by using a Bruker AVIII HD 600 MHz spectrometer, equipped with a triple resonance Prodigy N2 cryoprobe with a z-axis pulse field gradient, at the NMR laboratory of the Department of Environmental, Biological and Pharmaceutical Science and Technology (University of Campania “Luigi Vanvitelli”). The AIF(381–389) samples were prepared by dissolving 0.75 mg of the unlabeled peptide in 200 μL of PBS pH 7.4 with 10% D2O. The pH was finally adjusted to 5.8. 1H, 15N, and 13C chemical shift assignments of the unlabeled oxidized AIF(381–389) peptide in the free form and upon addition of CypA (molar ratio peptide/protein 150:1) were carried out by exploring the natural isotopic abundance through the use of NMR pulse sequences optimized, as reported in a previous publication.(31) In brief, the following spectra were acquired and analyzed: (i) homonuclear 2D [1H–1H] TOCSY,(52) 2D [1H–1H] NOESY(53) and 2D [1H–1H] ROESY(54) were acquired using 32 (64 for ROESY) for scans per t1 increment, a spectral width (SW) of 7211.54 Hz along both dimensions, a 3.0 s relaxation delay and 2048 × 256 complex points in t2 and t1, respectively. In particular, 2D [1H–1H] TOCSY spectra were acquired using a homonuclear Hartman–Hahn transfer through a MLEV(17) sequence using a mixing time of 70 ms and 10 KHz spin-lock field strength; 2D [1H–1H] NOESY experiments were reordered with a mixing time of 250 ms; 2D [1H–1H] ROESY spectra were measured with a CW spin-lock field strength of 4 kHz, a mixing time of 250 ms, and 5.0 s relaxation delay. In all homonuclear 2D experiments, water suppression was achieved by means of water-gate pulse sequence with gradients using double echo. 2D [1H–1H] spectra were apodized with a square cosine window function and zero fill to a matrix of size 4096 × 4096 before Fourier transform and baseline correction; (ii) heteronuclear 2D [1H–15N] HSQC experiments were acquired using 880 scans per t1 increment, a SW of 1581.26 Hz along t1 and 7211.54 Hz along t2, 2048 × 128 complex points in t2 and t1, respectively, and 1.0 s relaxation delay. [1H–15N] HSQC spectra were apodized with a square cosine window function and a zero filling to a matrix of size 4096 × 4096 before Fourier transform and baseline correction. Heteronuclear 2D [1H–13C] HSQC constant-time version ([1H–13C] CT HSQC) spectra were measured with 800 scans per t1 increment, a SW of 5131.08 Hz along t1 and 7211.54 Hz along t2, 2048 × 200 complex points in t2 and t1, respectively, and 1.0 s relaxation delay. 2D [1H–13C] CT HSQC spectra were performed with a coupling constant JXH = 145 Hz, constant time period of 13.3 ms, and were apodized with a square cosine window function and zero filled to a matrix of size 4096 × 4096 before Fourier transform and baseline correction. Microsecond-to-millisecond timescale backbone dynamics characterization of the unlabeled AIF(381–389) peptide was performed by evaluating the 15N R2 relaxation rate through natural abundance T2-filter [1H–15N] HSQC measurements acquired with the following acquisition parameters: 880 scans per t1 increment, SW of 1581.26 Hz along t1 and 7211.54 Hz along t2, 2048 × 128 complex points in t2 and t1, respectively, and 1.0 s relaxation delay. 2D T2-filter [1H–15N] HSQC experiments31 were carried out by using two different relaxation-compensated CPMG (Carr–Purcell–Meiboom–Gill) periods (125 and 500 ms) and were apodized with a square cosine window function and a zero filling to a matrix of size 4096 × 4096 before Fourier transform and baseline correction.
    Amide temperature coefficients (ΔδNH/ΔT (ppb/K)) and 3JHNHα couplings constants for the free AIF(381–389) peptide were obtained by measuring one-dimensional (1D) 1H spectra with the following acquisition parameters: SW of 7211.54 Hz, relaxation delay 5.0 s, 128 K data points for acquisition, and 256 K for transformation. ΔδNH/ΔT values were obtained from a series of 1D 1H experiments measured at 298, 300, 302, 304, 306, 308, and 310 K. The AIF(381–389) residues with ΔδNH/ΔT larger than −4.6 ppb/K were considered to be involved in hydrogen bonding(55,56) in the structure calculation (see below).
    To define the AIF(381–389) binding site on CypA by CSP studies, the 2D [1H–15N] HSQC spectra were recorded on His-tagged 15N-labeled CypA (80 μM) in the presence of increasing concentrations of AIF(381–389) peptide ranging from 0 to 800 μM in PBS buffer pH 5.8. 2D [1H–15N] HSQC spectra were measured using eight scans per t1 increment, a SW of 2160.76 Hz along t1 and 7201.56 Hz along t2, 1024 × 128 complex points in t2 and t1, respectively, and 1.0 s relaxation delay. [1H–15N] HSQC spectra were apodized with a square cosine window function and a zero filling to a matrix of size 2048 × 1024 before Fourier transform and baseline correction. The spectra were processed using NMRpipe(57) and analyzed using SPARKY(58) and CARA(59) software. 1H, 13C, and 15N chemical shifts were calibrated indirectly by external sodium 2,2-dimethyl-2-silapentane-5-sulfonate (DSS) references.

    Chemical Shift Analysis

    For the AIF(381–389) peptide, the secondary chemical shifts (Δδ) of Hα, Cα and Cβ nuclei were calculated as the difference between the observed chemical shifts (δobs) and the random coil shifts (δcoil). These latter values were predicted from the AIF(381–389) amino-acid sequence by using different methodologies defined by Wishart and Sykes,(38) De Simone and Sanz-Hernández,(36) Kjaergaard et al.,(34,35) and Tamiola and Mulder.(37) In the last two cases, the chemical shifts of the CysN-ter and CysC-ter were not included in the data analysis. Additionally, the structural investigation of AIF(381–389) was performed by analyzing the difference between Cα and Cβ secondary chemical shifts (ΔδCα–ΔδCβ).(39) In particular, consecutive positive values of ΔδCα–ΔδCβ (+2 ppm) indicate α-helix structure and negative values (−2 ppm) indicate the β-strand or extended structure.
    The prediction of the redox state of CysN-ter and CysC-ter contained in the AIF(381–389) peptide was performed by comparing the cysteine Cα and Cβ chemical shifts with the reference values in accordance with the procedure proposed by Rajarathnam and co-workers.(42) The structural rearrangements of AIF(381–389) induced by CypA binding were estimated by applying a weighted combined 1H (ΔδH), 15N (ΔδN) and 13C (ΔδC) CSPs based on the following equationwhere WH, WN, and WC are the weighing factors for the 1H, 15N, and 13C shifts defined as WH = |γH/γH| = 1; WN = |γN/γH| = 0.101; WC = |γC/γH| = 0.251. ΔδH, ΔδN, and ΔδC are the chemical shift differences in parts per million between the compared protein states for 1H, 15N, and 13C, respectively; γH, γN, and γC are the gyromagnetic ratios. The AIF(381–389) CSPs were evaluated by dividing the chemical shifts in three groups: backbone (HN, Hα, Cα, and N), side chains, and all together. In the case of CypA, the CSP analysis was performed using the backbone HN and N shifts. The model-free order parameter S2 for the AIF(381–389) backbone amide group were predicted from HN, Hα, Cα, N, and Cβ chemical shifts using a random coil index approach in accordance with the chemical shift-based methodology developed by Berjanskii and Wishart.(60,61)

    Structure Determination of AIF(381–389)

    The NMR structure of AIF(381–389) was calculated with the program CYANA 3.0(62) using ROE-derived distance constraints, backbone dihedral angles, and hydrogen bonds. In particular, backbone dihedral angles were obtained using NMR chemical shifts by TALOS+;(63) whereas the hydrogen bonds were defined for residues showing amide temperature coefficients larger than −4.6 ppb/K. The input restraints for the final structure are reported in Table S5. In particular, the NMR conformational ensemble of AIF(381–389) was calculated using (i) a total of 151 distance constraints (30 sequential and 23 nonsequential) from the ROEs (Figure 3A,B and Table S6), (ii) 3 hydrogen bonds identified from the amide proton temperature coefficients (ΔδHN/ΔT) (Table S5), and (iii) 12 TALOS + dihedral angle restraints derived from Hα, HN, N, Cα, and Cβ chemical shifts.
    A total of 100 structures were calculated, and the 20 conformers having the lowest CYANA target function were selected to generate the final NMR conformational ensemble. The absence of residual constraint violations demonstrates that the input data represent a self-consistent set and the restraints are well satisfied in the calculated structures. The NMR structures were visualized and evaluated by using the programs MOLMOL,(64) CHIMERA,(65) and PROCHECK-NMR.(66)

    Generation of the CypA Conformational Ensemble

    In order to provide a rigorous description of the conformational space sampled by the CypA protein, we used a conformational sampling approach to generate a pool of CypA conformers. The normal mode-based simulation (NMSim) methodology has been demonstrated to be a computationally efficient alternative to molecular dynamics simulations for conformational sampling of proteins.(67) Therefore, an ensemble of 500 conformers was generated with the software NMSim, starting from the CypA reference structure that was generated by applying a mild minimization to the protonated X-ray structure (PDB ID code: 2CPL) (pH 5.8), in which explicit hydrogens were added using the software H2+.(68) In particular, the minimization was performed by the software SPDB,(69) whereas the conformational ensemble was generated using the default NMSim parameters suitable for large motions. Then, the conformational ensemble was clustered by using the software NMRCLUST(70) implemented in the program CHIMERA.(65) A total of 51 clusters were found, and for each of them, the representative structure was considered to obtain the final MD ensemble. The adaptive Poisson–Boltzmann solver(71) was used to calculate spatial distributions of CypA electrostatic potentials using the linearized Poisson–Boltzmann equation and parameters from the PQR files of the CypA X-ray structure obtained using the PDB2PQR server.(72) The CypA electrostatic map was generated with CHIMERA.

    Molecular Docking Calculation

    The software HADDOCK(44,45) was used to dock the peptide AIF(381–389) to the protein CypA using AIRs identified according to the NMR data (i.e., CSP and intensity ratio analysis) and solvent-accessible CypA residues defined by using the ProtSA approach.(73) Six residues (Thr68, Arg69, Gly72, Gly75, Asn102, and Ala103) of CypA, showing significant chemical shift, and NMR signal intensity variations upon binding to AIF(381–389) with >40% solvent accessibility were defined as “active” residues, whereas for the AIF(381–389) peptide, four residues (Lys382, Asp385, Arg387, and Lys388) were selected as “active” according to the CSPs and HN/N signal intensity profile. In both cases, the “passive” amino acids were automatically selected by the program HADDOCK. The starting structures of AIF(381–389) for docking were the 20 conformers of the NMR ensemble calculated as reported below, while for CypA, the MD ensemble (51 structures) was generated by molecular dynamics simulations and cluster analysis (as described above). The structural model of the AIF(381–389)/CypA complex was performed following the HADDOCK 2.2 protocol using optimal setting parameters for docking of peptides (i.e., number of MD steps for rigid-body high temperature TAD = 2000; number of MD steps during the first rigid body cooling stage = 2000; number of MD steps during the second cooling stage with flexible side chains at the interface = 4000; number of MD steps during the third cooling stage with fully flexible interface = 4000).(45) In particular, during rigid-body energy minimization, 2000 docking conformers were calculated. The best 200 structures in terms of intermolecular energies were then used for the semiflexible simulating annealing, followed by explicit water refinement. Then, the obtained structures were clustered using a 5 Å rmsd as the cutoff based on the pairwise backbone rmsd. The representative structure from the lowest energy cluster (cluster 1), containing 41 structures, which had the lowest HADDOCK/Z-score and was more in line with the NMR experimental data, was accepted as reference structural model of the complex. The selected AIF(381–389)/CypA structure was analyzed and visualized using the software CHIMERA. The 2D interaction scheme of the AIF(381–389)/CypA complex was obtained and visualized using PIC(74) and Schrodinger Maestro software. The sequence conservation profile of CypA was calculated using the ConSurf server (https://consurf.tau.ac.il). The in silico alanine scanning for the AIF(381–389) residues was performed by the DrugScore web server (https://cpclab.uni-duesseldorf.de/index.php/Web-Server) using the selected PDB file of the AIF(381–389)/CypA complex as input.

      1
      The crystal structure of the mouse apoptosis-inducing factor AIF
      Mate, Maria J.; Ortiz-Lombardia, Miguel; Boitel, Brigitte; Haouz, Ahmed; Tello, Diana; Susin, Santos A.; Penninger, Josef; Kroemer, Guido; Alzari, Pedro M.
      Nature Structural Biology (2002), 9 (6), 442-446CODEN: NSBIEW; ISSN:1072-8368. (Nature America Inc.)
      Mitochondria play a key role in apoptosis due to their capacity to release potentially lethal proteins. One of these latent death factors is cytochrome c, which can stimulate the proteolytic activation of caspase zymogens. Another important protein is apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF), a 57-kDa electron-transferring flavoprotein oxidoreductase, which can stimulate a caspase-independent cell-death pathway required for early embryonic morphogenesis. Here, the authors report the crystal structure of mouse mitochondrial AIF at 2.0 Å. Its active site structure and redox properties suggest that AIF functions as an electron transferase with a mechanism similar to that of the bacterial ferredoxin reductases, its closest evolutionary homologs. However, AIF structurally differs from these proteins in some essential features, including a long insertion in a C-terminal β-hairpin loop, which may be related to its apoptogenic functions.

      Apoptosis-inducing factor: structure, function, and redox regulation
      Sevrioukova, Irina F.
      Antioxidants & Redox Signaling (2011), 14 (12), 2545-2579CODEN: ARSIF2; ISSN:1523-0864. (Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.)
      A review. Apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF) is a FAD-contg., NADH-dependent oxidoreductase residing in the mitochondrial intermembrane space whose specific enzymic activity remains unknown. Upon an apoptotic insult, AIF undergoes proteolysis and translocates to the nucleus, where it triggers chromatin condensation and large-scale DNA degrdn. in a caspase-independent manner. In addn. to playing a key role in the execution of caspase-independent cell death, AIF has emerged as a protein crit. for cell survival. Anal. of in vivo phenotypes assocd. with AIF deficiency and defects, and identification of its mitochondrial, cytoplasmic, and nuclear partners has revealed the complexity and multi-level regulation of AIF-mediated signal transduction and has suggested an important role of AIF in the maintenance of mitochondrial morphol. and energy metab. The redox activity of AIF is essential for optimal oxidative phosphorylation. Addnl., the protein is proposed to regulate the respiratory chain indirectly, through assembly and/or stabilization of complexes I and III. Here, the author discusses accumulated data with respect to AIF structure and outlines evidence that supports the prevalent mechanistic view on the apoptogenic actions of the flavoprotein, as well as the emerging concept of AIF as a redox sensor capable of linking NAD(H)-dependent metabolic pathways to apoptosis.

      The harlequin mouse mutation downregulates apoptosis-inducing factor
      Klein, Jeffrey A.; Longo-Guess, Chantal M.; Rossmann, Marlies P.; Seburn, Kevin L.; Hurd, Ronald E.; Frankel, Wayne N.; Bronson, Roderick T.; Ackerman, Susan L.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2002), 419 (6905), 367-374CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Harlequin (Hq) mutant mice have progressive degeneration of terminally differentiated cerebellar and retinal neurons. The authors have identified the Hq mutation as a proviral insertion in the apoptosis-inducing factor (Aif) gene, causing about an 80% redn. in AIF expression. Mutant cerebellar granule cells are susceptible to exogenous and endogenous peroxide-mediated apoptosis, but can be rescued by AIF expression. Overexpression of AIF in wild-type granule cells further decreases peroxide-mediated cell death, suggesting that AIF serves as a free radical scavenger. In agreement, dying neurons in aged Hq mutant mice show oxidative stress. In addn., neurons damaged by oxidative stress in both the cerebellum and retina of Hq mutant mice re-enter the cell cycle before undergoing apoptosis. Our results provide a genetic model of oxidative stress-mediated neurodegeneration and demonstrate a direct connection between cell cycle re-entry and oxidative stress in the ageing central nervous system.

      Cyclophilin A participates in the nuclear translocation of apoptosis-inducing factor in neurons after cerebral hypoxia-ischemia
      Zhu, Changlian; Wang, Xiaoyang; Deinum, Johanna; Huang, Zhiheng; Gao, Jianfeng; Modjtahedi, Nazanine; Neagu, Martha R.; Nilsson, Michael; Eriksson, Peter S.; Hagberg, Henrik; Luban, Jeremy; Kroemer, Guido; Blomgren, Klas
      Journal of Experimental Medicine (2007), 204 (8), 1741-1748CODEN: JEMEAV; ISSN:0022-1007. (Rockefeller University Press)
      Upon cerebral hypoxia-ischemia (HI), apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF) can move from mitochondria to nuclei, participate in chromatinolysis, and contribute to the execution of cell death. Previous work performed in vitro suggests that AIF must interact with cyclophilin A (CypA) to form a proapoptotic DNA degrdn. complex. The authors addressed the question as to whether elimination of CypA may afford neuroprotection in vivo. 9-D-old wild-type (WT), CypA+/-, or CypA-/- mice were subjected to unilateral cerebral HI. The infarct vol. after HI was reduced by 47% in CypA-/- mice compared with their WT littermates. Importantly, CypA-/- neurons failed to manifest the HI-induced nuclear translocation of AIF that was obsd. in WT neurons. Conversely, CypA accumulated within the nuclei of damaged neurons after HI, and this nuclear translocation of CypA was suppressed in AIF-deficient harlequin mice. Immunopptn. of AIF revealed copptn. of CypA, but only in injured, ischemic tissue. Surface plasmon resonance revealed direct mol. interactions between recombinant AIF and CypA. These data indicate that the lethal translocation of AIF to the nucleus requires interaction with CypA, suggesting a model in which two proteins that normally reside in sep. cytoplasmic compartments acquire novel properties when moving together to the nucleus.

      Apoptosis-inducing factor: vital and lethal
      Modjtahedi, Nazanine; Giordanetto, Fabrizio; Madeo, Frank; Kroemer, Guido
      Trends in Cell Biology (2006), 16 (5), 264-272CODEN: TCBIEK; ISSN:0962-8924. (Elsevier)
      A review. Apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF) is a NADH oxidase with a local redox function that is essential for optimal oxidative phosphorylation and for an efficient anti-oxidant defense. The absence of AIF can cause neurodegeneration, skeleton muscle atrophy and dilated cardiomyopathy. In many models of apoptosis, AIF translocates to the nucleus, where it induces chromatin condensation and DNA degrdn. The nuclear localization of AIF can be inhibited by blocking upstream signals of apoptosis. The contribution of AIF to cell death depends on the cell type and apoptotic insult and is only seen when caspases are inhibited or not activated. It is unknown to what extent and through which mechanisms AIF contributes to the induction of cell death. Here, we discuss recent progress in the quest to understand the contribution of AIF to life and death.

      Apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF): key to the conserved caspase-independent pathways of cell death?
      Cande, Celine; Cecconi, Francesco; Dessen, Philippe; Kroemer, Guido
      Journal of Cell Science (2002), 115 (24), 4727-4734CODEN: JNCSAI; ISSN:0021-9533. (Company of Biologists Ltd.)
      A review. Numerous pro-apoptotic signal transducing mols. act on mitochondria and provoke the permeabilization of the outer mitochondrial membrane, thereby triggering the release of potentially toxic mitochondrial proteins. One of these proteins, apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF), is a phylogenetically old flavoprotein which, in healthy cells, is confined to the mitochondrial intermembrane space. Upon lethal signaling, AIF translocates, via the cytosol, to the nucleus where it binds to DNA and provokes caspase-independent chromatin condensation. The crystal structures of both human and mouse AIF have been detd., and the fine mechanisms accounting for its oxidoreductase activity and its electrostatic interaction with double-stranded DNA have been elucidated. Importantly, the apoptogenic and oxidoreductase functions of AIF can be dissocd. Thus, mutations that abolish the AIF-DNA interaction suppress AIF-induced chromatin condensation, yet have no effect on the NADH oxidase activity. Recent studies suggest AIF to be a major factor detg. caspase-independent neuronal death, emphasizing the central role of mitochondria in the control of physiol. and pathol. cell demise.

      Apoptosis-inducing factor is involved in the regulation of caspase-independent neuronal cell death
      Cregan, Sean P.; Fortin, Andre; MacLaurin, Jason G.; Callaghan, Steven M.; Cecconi, Francesco; Yu, Seong-Woon; Dawson, Ted M.; Dawson, Valina L.; Park, David S.; Kroemer, Guido; Slack, Ruth S.
      Journal of Cell Biology (2002), 158 (3), 507-517CODEN: JCLBA3; ISSN:0021-9525. (Rockefeller University Press)
      Caspase-independent death mechanisms have been shown to execute apoptosis in many types of neuronal injury. P53 has been identified as a key regulator of neuronal cell death after acute injury such as DNA damage, ischemia, and excitotoxicity. Here, we demonstrate that p53 can induce neuronal cell death via a caspase-mediated process activated by apoptotic activating factor-1 (Apaf1) and via a delayed onset caspase-independent mechanism. In contrast to wild-type cells, Apaf1-deficient neurons exhibit delayed DNA fragmentation and only peripheral chromatin condensation. More importantly, we demonstrate that apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF) is an important factor involved in the regulation of this caspase-independent neuronal cell death. Immunofluorescence studies demonstrate that AIF is released from the mitochondria by a mechanism distinct from that of cytochrome-c in neurons undergoing p53-mediated cell death. The Bcl-2 family regulates this release of AIF and subsequent caspase-independent cell death. In addn., we show that enforced expression of AIF can induce neuronal cell death in a Bax- and caspase-independent manner. Microinjection of neutralizing antibodies against AIF significantly decreased injury-induced neuronal cell death in Apaf1-deficient neurons, indicating its importance in caspase-independent apoptosis. Taken together, our results suggest that AIF may be an important therapeutic target for the treatment of neuronal injury.

      Molecular characterization of mitochondrial apoptosis-inducing factor
      Susin, Santos A.; Lorenzo, Hans K.; Zamzami, Naoufal; Marzo, Isabel; Snow, Bryan E.; Brothers, Greg M.; Mangion, Joan; Jacotot, Etienne; Costantini, Paola; Loeffler, Markus; Larochette, Nathanael; Goodlett, David R.; Aebersold, Ruedi; Siderovski, David P.; Penninger, Josef M.; Kroemer, Guido
      Nature (London) (1999), 397 (6718), 441-446CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
      Mitochondria play a key part in the regulation of apoptosis (cell death). Their intermembrane space contains several proteins that are liberated through the outer membrane in order to participate in the degrdn. phase of apoptosis. Here we report the identification and cloning of an apoptosis-inducing factor, AIF5, which is sufficient to induce apoptosis of isolated nuclei. AIF is a flavoprotein of relative mol. mass 57,000 which shares homol. with the bacterial oxidoreductases; it is normally confined to mitochondria but translocates to the nucleus when apoptosis is induced. Recombinant AIF causes chromatin condensation in isolated nuclei and large-scale fragmentation of DNA. It induces purified mitochondria to release the apoptogenic proteins cytochrome c and caspase-9. Microinjection of AIF into the cytoplasm of intact cells induces condensation of chromatin, dissipation of the mitochondrial transmembrane potential, and exposure of phosphatidylserine in the plasma membrane. None of these effects is prevented by the wide-ranging caspase inhibitor known as Z-VAD.fmk. Overexpression of Bcl-2, which controls the opening of mitochondrial permeability transition pores, prevents the release of AIF from the mitochondrion but does not affect its apoptogenic activity. These results indicate that AIF is a mitochondrial effector of apoptotic cell death.

      Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease characterized by selective loss of motor neurons in the brain stem and the spinal cords. One of the causes for the familial ALS has been attributed to the mutations in copper-zinc superoxide dismutase (SOD1). Although the toxic function of the mutant enzyme has not been fully understood, the final cell death pathway has been suggested as caspase-dependent.       Mediation of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase-1-dependent cell death by apoptosis-inducing factor
      Yu, Seong-Woon; Wang, Hongmin; Poitras, Marc F.; Coombs, Carmen; Bowers, William J.; Federoff, Howard J.; Poirier, Guy G.; Dawson, Ted M.; Dawson, Valina L.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 297 (5579), 259-263CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase-1 (PARP-1) protects the genome by functioning in the DNA damage surveillance network. PARP- 1 is also a mediator of cell death after ischemia-reperfusion injury, glutamate excitotoxicity, and various inflammatory processes. We show that PARP-1 activation is required for translocation of apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF) from the mitochondria to the nucleus and that AIF is necessary for PARP-1-dependent cell death.       Intranuclear localization of apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF) and large scale DNA fragmentation after traumatic brain injury in rats and in neuronal cultures exposed to peroxynitrite
      Zhang, Xiaopeng; Chen, Jun; Graham, Steven H.; Du, Lina; Kochanek, Patrick M.; Draviam, Romesh; Guo, Fengli; Nathaniel, Paula D.; Szabo, Csaba; Watkins, Simon C.; Clark, Robert S. B.
      Journal of Neurochemistry (2002), 82 (1), 181-191CODEN: JONRA9; ISSN:0022-3042. (Blackwell Science Ltd.)
      Programmed cell death occurs after ischemic, excitotoxic, and traumatic brain injury (TBI). Recently, a caspase-independent pathway involving intranuclear translocation of mitochondrial apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF) has been reported in vitro; but whether this occurs after acute brain injury was unknown. To address this question adult rats were sacrificed at various times after TBI. Western blot anal. on subcellular protein fractions demonstrated intranuclear localization of AIF in ipsilateral cortex and hippocampus at 2-72 h. Immunocytochem. anal. showed AIF labeling in neuronal nuclei with DNA fragmentation in the ipsilateral cortex and hippocampus. Immunoelectronmicroscopy verified intranuclear localization of AIF in hippocampal neurons after TBI, primarily in regions of euchromatin. Large-scale DNA fragmentation (∼50 kbp), a signature event in AIF-mediated cell death, was detected in ipsilateral cortex and hippocampi by 6 h. Neuron-enriched cultures exposed to peroxynitrite also demonstrated intranuclear AIF and large-scale DNA fragmentation concurrent with impaired mitochondrial respiration and cell death, events that are inhibited by treatment with a peroxynitrite decompn. catalyst. Intranuclear localization of AIF and large-scale DNA fragmentation occurs after TBI and in neurons under conditions of oxidative/nitrosative stress, providing the first evidence of this alternative mechanism by which programmed cell death may proceed in neurons after brain injury.

      Over-expression of HSP70 attenuates caspase-dependent and caspase-independent pathways and inhibits neuronal apoptosis
      Sabirzhanov, Boris; Stoica, Bogdan A.; Hanscom, Marie; Piao, Chun-Shu; Faden, Alan I.
      Journal of Neurochemistry (2012), 123 (3&4), 542-554CODEN: JONRA9; ISSN:0022-3042. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      HSP70 is a member of the family of heat-shock proteins that are known to be up-regulated in neurons following injury and/or stress. HSP70 over-expression has been linked to neuroprotection in multiple models, including neurodegenerative disorders. In contrast, less is known about the neuroprotective effects of HSP70 in neuronal apoptosis and with regard to modulation of programmed cell death (PCD) mechanisms in neurons. The authors examd. the effects of HSP70 over-expression by transfection with HSP70-expression plasmids in primary cortical neurons and the SH-SY5Y neuronal cell line using four independent models of apoptosis: etoposide, staurosporine, C2-ceramide, and β-Amyloid. In these apoptotic models, neurons transfected with the HSP70 construct showed significantly reduced induction of nuclear apoptotic markers and/or cell death. Furthermore, the authors demonstrated that HSP70 binds and potentially inactivates Apoptotic protease-activating factor 1, as well as apoptosis-inducing factor, key mols. involved in development of caspase-dependent and caspase-independent PCD, resp. Markers of caspase-dependent PCD, including active caspase-3, caspase-9, and cleaved PARP were attenuated in neurons over-expressing HSP70. These data indicate that HSP70 protects against neuronal apoptosis and suggest that these effects reflect, at least in part, to inhibition of both caspase-dependent and caspase-independent PCD pathways.

      AIF depletion provides neuroprotection through a preconditioning effect
      Oxler Eva-Maria; Dolga Amalia; Culmsee C
      Apoptosis : an international journal on programmed cell death (2012), 17 (10), 1027-38 ISSN:.
      Previous studies established a major role for apoptosis inducing factor (AIF) in neuronal cell death after acute brain injury. For example, AIF translocation from mitochondria to the nucleus determined delayed neuronal death, whereas reduced AIF expression provided neuroprotective effects in models of cerebral ischemia or brain trauma. The question remains, however, why reduced AIF levels are sufficient to mediate neuroprotection, since only very little AIF translocation to the nucleus is required for induction of cell death. Thus, the present study addresses the question, whether AIF gene silencing affects intrinsic death pathways upstream of nuclear translocation at the level of the mitochondria. Using MTT assays and real-time cell impedance measurements we confirmed the protective effect of AIF siRNA against glutamate toxicity in immortalized mouse hippocampal HT-22 neurons. Further, AIF siRNA prevented glutamate-induced mitochondrial fragmentation and loss of mitochondrial membrane potential. The protection of mitochondrial integrity was associated with preserved ATP levels, attenuated increases in lipid peroxidation and reduced complex I expression levels. Notably, low concentrations of the complex I inhibitor rotenone (20 nM), provided similar protective effects against glutamate toxicity at the mitochondrial level. These results expose a preconditioning effect as a mechanism for neuroprotection mediated by AIF depletion. In particular, they point out an association between mitochondrial complex I and AIF, which regulate each other's stability in mitochondria. Overall, these findings postulate that AIF depletion mediates a preconditioning effect protecting neuronal cells from subsequent glutamate toxicity through reduced levels of complex I protein.

      Initiation of neuronal damage by complex I deficiency and oxidative stress in Parkinson's Disease
      Tretter, Laszlo; Sipos, Ildiko; Adam-Vizi, Vera
      Neurochemical Research (2004), 29 (3), 569-577CODEN: NEREDZ; ISSN:0364-3190. (Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers)
      A review. Oxidative stress and partial deficiencies of mitochondrial complex I appear to be key factors in the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease. They are interconnected; complex I inhibition results in an enhanced prodn. of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which in turn will inhibit complex I. Partial inhibition of complex I in nerve terminals is sufficient for in situ mitochondria to generate more ROS. H2O2 plays a major role in inhibiting complex I as well as a key metabolic enzyme, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. The vicious cycle resulting from partial inhibition of complex I and/or an inherently higher ROS prodn. in dopaminergic neurons leads over time to excessive oxidative stress and ATP deficit that eventually will result in cell death in the nigro-striatal pathway.

      AIF promotes chromatinolysis and caspase-independent programmed necrosis by interacting with histone H2AX
      Artus, Cedric; Boujrad, Hanan; Bouharrour, Aida; Brunelle, Marie-Noelle; Hoos, Sylviane; Yuste, Victor J.; Lenormand, Pascal; Rousselle, Jean-Claude; Namane, Abdelkader; England, Patrick; Lorenzo, Hans K.; Susin, Santos A.
      EMBO Journal (2010), 29 (9), 1585-1599CODEN: EMJODG; ISSN:0261-4189. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Programmed necrosis induced by DNA alkylating agents, such as MNNG, is a caspase-independent mode of cell death mediated by apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF). After poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase 1, calpain, and Bax activation, AIF moves from the mitochondria to the nucleus where it induces chromatinolysis and cell death. The mechanisms underlying the nuclear action of AIF are, however, largely unknown. We show here that, through its C-terminal proline-rich binding domain (PBD, residues 543-559), AIF assocs. in the nucleus with histone H2AX. This interaction regulates chromatinolysis and programmed necrosis by generating an active DNA-degrading complex with cyclophilin A (CypA). We also establish that H2AX is phosphorylated at Ser139 after MNNG treatment and that this phosphorylation is crit. for caspase-independent programmed necrosis. Overall, our data shed new light in the mechanisms regulating programmed necrosis, elucidate a key nuclear partner of AIF, and uncover an AIF apoptogenic motif.

      Apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF), a key regulator of cell death, is essential for normal mammalian development and participates in pathol. apoptosis.       A Minimal Peptide Scaffold for β-Turn Display: Optimizing a Strand Position in Disulfide-Cyclized β-Hairpins
      Cochran, Andrea G.; Tong, Ricky T.; Starovasnik, Melissa A.; Park, Eleanor J.; McDowell, Robert S.; Theaker, J. E.; Skelton, Nicholas J.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2001), 123 (4), 625-632CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Phage display of peptide libraries has become a powerful tool for the evolution of novel ligands that bind virtually any protein target. However, the rules governing conformational preferences in natural peptides are poorly understood, and consequently, structure-activity relationships in these mols. can be difficult to define. In an effort to simplify this process, we have investigated the structural stability of 10-residue, disulfide-constrained β-hairpins and assessed their suitability as scaffolds for β-turn display. Using disulfide formation as a probe, relative free energies of folding were measured for 19 peptides that differ at a one strand position. A tryptophan substitution promotes folding to a remarkable degree. NMR anal. confirms that the measured energies correlate well with the degree of β-hairpin structure in the disulfide-cyclized peptides. Reexamn. of a subset of the strand substitutions in peptides with different turn sequences reveals linear free energy relationships, indicating that turns and strand-strand interactions make independent, additive contributions to hairpin stability. Significantly, the tryptophan strand substitution is highly stabilizing with all turns tested, and peptides that display model turns or the less stable C'-C'' turn of CD4 on this tryptophan "stem" are highly structured β-hairpins in water. Thus, we have developed a small, structured β-turn scaffold, contg. only natural L-amino acids, that may be used to display peptide libraries of limited conformational diversity on phage.

      A simple technique for identifying protein secondary structures through the anal. of backbone 13C chem. shifts is described. It is based on the Chem.-Shift Index [Wishart et al. (1992)] which was originally developed for the anal. of 1Hα chem. shifts. By extending the Chem.-Shift Index to include 13Cα, 13Cβ and carbonyl 13C chem. shifts, it is now possible to use four independent chem.-shift measurements to identify and locate protein secondary structures. It is shown that by combining both 1H and 13C chem.-shift indexes to produce a 'consensus' est. of secondary structure, it is possible to achieve a predictive accuracy in excess of 92%. This suggests that the secondary structure of peptides and proteins can be accurately obtained from 1H and 13C chem. shifts, without recourse to NOE measurements.

      Random coil chemical shift for intrinsically disordered proteins: effects of temperature and pH
      Kjaergaard, Magnus; Brander, Soren; Poulsen, Flemming M.
      Journal of Biomolecular NMR (2011), 49 (2), 139-149CODEN: JBNME9; ISSN:0925-2738. (Springer)
      Secondary chem. shift anal. is the main NMR method for detection of transiently formed secondary structure in intrinsically disordered proteins. The pH dependence of the histidine random coil chem. shifts is investigated in a titrn. series, which allows the accurate random coil chem. shifts to be obtained at any pH. By correcting the random coil chem. shifts for the effects of temp. and pH, systematic biases of the secondary chem. shifts are minimized, which will improve the reliability of detection of transient secondary structure in disordered proteins.
